script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi there! I'm Dr. Martinez. And who do we have here today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: This is Emma. She's been complaining about her throat hurting since yesterday.

script.speaker: child
script.text: My throat is owwy!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh no, Emma! That doesn't sound fun at all. Can you tell me how much it hurts? Like a little bit or a lot?

script.speaker: child
script.text: A lot! It hurts when I swallow.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm sorry to hear that, sweetie. Mom, when did you first notice she wasn't feeling well?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She woke up yesterday morning saying her throat hurt. She didn't want to eat breakfast, which is unusual for her. No fever that I noticed initially.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has she had any fever since then?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, I took her temperature last night and it was 101.2. This morning it was 100.8.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Emma, have you been feeling hot or cold?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Hot. And tired.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any headache, honey?

script.speaker: child
script.text: A little bit.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's also been more clingy than usual and took a long nap yesterday, which she rarely does anymore.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has she had any runny nose, cough, or ear pain?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No runny nose or cough. She hasn't mentioned her ears hurting.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any nausea or vomiting?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No vomiting, but she's barely eaten anything since yesterday.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Emma, I'm going to look in your throat now, okay? Can you open your mouth really wide for me like a lion? Roar!

script.speaker: child
script.text: Roooar!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect! Now say 'ahh' for me.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Ahhhh

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can see her throat is quite red and swollen. Let me feel her neck for any swollen glands.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Emma, I'm just going to feel under your chin and on your neck. It might feel a little funny but it won't hurt.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, I can feel some enlarged lymph nodes. Has she been around anyone with strep throat recently?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Her daycare sent home a note last week saying there were a few cases of strep going around.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That makes sense. Based on her symptoms and what I'm seeing on exam, this looks very much like strep throat. I'd like to do a quick test to confirm.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Is that the throat swab?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Exactly. Emma, I need to use a long cotton swab to touch the back of your throat. It might feel yucky for just a second, but then we'll be all done.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Will it hurt?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It won't hurt, but it might make you feel like you want to gag for just one second. You're being so brave!

script.speaker: parent
script.text: You can squeeze my hand, Emma.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The rapid test is positive for strep. I'll start her on antibiotics, and she should start feeling better within 24 to 48 hours.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Good, I was hoping we caught it early. What antibiotic will you prescribe?
